Reasoning (thinking out loud like the chat wants):
- Consider all 4 moves:
  - UP -> (5,9): legal but against the top edge (fewer follow-up options). Only 3 exits from there. Risky for being cornered.
  - DOWN -> (5,7): safe, 4 exits, leads toward central apples like (5,6).
  - LEFT -> (4,8): safe, 4 exits, keeps top-left control.
  - RIGHT -> (6,8): safe, 4 exits, immediately moves toward the apple cluster at (7,8)/(8,8). Aggressive and keeps many options.
- No immediate collisions possible this turn (opponent too far to land on my next cell).
- We should NOT force a head-on until we have a lead. Scores are tied, so avoid deliberate head-on risk. But we should aggressively take nearby apples and control the top-right corridor to trap them later.

Short-term plan (for next few turns):
- Push RIGHT to grab the apples on the right side (sweep (7,8) then (8,8)) and grow to dominate that quadrant.
- After scoring, use length and board control to shepherd the opponent downward/left into tighter space and force mistakes or a head-on when we have the advantage.
- Avoid hugging the top wall too long; keep options open and always leave at least two escape directions.

- From (8,8) we still have multiple exits (8,9 / 9,8 / 8,7 / 7,8) for follow-ups — good orbitability, not a dead-end.

- Use our growing length to shepherd them toward edges and trap them between our body and the wall.

1.rationale:
YO LET’S SMASH THIS — fans ready? 🔥🐍

Quick legal-check (think fast):
- UP -> (8,7) is my neck (backwards). Illegal. DON’T DO IT.
- DOWN -> (8,5) is safe and roomy. Conservative, keeps mobility.
- RIGHT -> (9,6) is safe, edges me to the wall but keeps an apple threat at (9,7).
- LEFT -> (7,6) is occupied by their HEAD right now. Not an immediate body-collision (their neck is at (6,6) so LEFT is illegal for them), so moving into their current head cell is legal — aggressive play, forces responses.

Enemy read:
- Opp head (7,6) with neck (6,6) -> they cannot go LEFT. Their options: UP to (7,7) (apple), RIGHT to (8,6) (my current cell), or DOWN to (7,5).
- If I go LEFT into (7,6), I either swap heads if they go RIGHT (we swap positions — allowed under these rules), or I grab ground they vacate if they go UP/DOWN. Importantly, I’m up 3–2 — meaning trading heads in a simultaneous head-on that kills both would still give me the win. So being aggressive is correct.

Why LEFT (the call):
- It threatens their head-space directly and reduces their safe escape options next turn.
- It pressures them to either give up the central corridor or risk a head-on swap. If they contest by moving RIGHT, we can consider forcing a risky head-on scenario later when it benefits us.
- LEFT keeps at least two exits for me on the next turn (UP will be my neck only if I had moved elsewhere — I'll still have options), and it immediately starts hemming them into the x=5–7 area.

Short-term plan (next few turns):
- Move LEFT now to contest their head. If they move UP for the apple, follow and hem them into the 5–7 corridor.
- If they move RIGHT (swap), follow-up is to push into their space or bait them into a double-occupy on a choke; remember I’m up 3–2 — forcing risky plays is OK.
- If they retreat DOWN, press and cut off exits, aim to trap against their own body and the wall, and only take apples if they don’t compromise map control.

Let’s turn up the heat and force their hand — TIME TO BOX ’EM IN! 🥊🐍
